instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.R6990: What is R6990? Resistor between charger voltage and input to PP3V42_G3H power supply on Macbooks from around the year 2012. This resistor blows when C6990 has shorted to ground or U6990 has shorted to ground, and will result in PP3V42_G3H missing and the magsafe charger not having a light since PP3V42_G3H is necessary for the SMC to turn on and the onewire circuit to turn on..
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - f6905
threads.message:
Guys,

I get in F6905 0.45 - 0.59 . 0.89v
The fuse is ok.
I replaced twice the magsafe and charger and i still don't get 16v.

Any advice?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - f6905
threads.message: Try with a fake chinese charger, the Apple one is shutting down because of an over current issue.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - f6905
threads.message: what is resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - f6905
threads.message: Well then there is obviously a short. Is there a short on <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> to GND or on L7030?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - f6905
threads.message: [USER="2"]dukefawks[/USER] You are right! I replaced <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> and i get green light, but <TRANSISTOR>Q7085</TRANSISTOR> get VERY HOT! I replaced twice and keep get warm.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - f6905
threads.message:
Why would you replace <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>?
I asked if there was a short to GND there, also check short the GND on <CAPACITOR>C7087</CAPACITOR>.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - f6905
threads.message:
Yes, have short to ground, that's why i replaced. I get green light after that.
I just check <CAPACITOR>C7087</CAPACITOR> short to ground and i get 12.89 m ohm.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - f6905
threads.message: I get on <RESISTOR>R7085</RESISTOR> 467 M ohm, but the schematics said 470K

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - f6905
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - f6905
threads.message:
Please for the love of God go and figure out how to use a multimeter. 12.89mOhm is milli Ohm. 467M Ohm on <RESISTOR>R7085</RESISTOR> is MEGA OHM. This all makes no sense at all AGAIN.
Also if there is a short to GND how would <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> be responsible for that, it is just impossible.
I cannot diagnose your issues if you have no clue what you are measuring or doing, sorry.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - f6905
threads.message:
I fixed!

Comp. Replaced:
1 - <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>
2 - <TRANSISTOR>Q7085</TRANSISTOR>
3 - <CAPACITOR>C7030</CAPACITOR>
4 - <CAPACITOR>C7031</CAPACITOR>

I will buy a new Multimeter

Thanks [USER="2"]dukefawks[/USER] [USER="1"]larossmann[/USER]

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - f6905
threads.message:
It was of course a shorted <CAPACITOR>C7030</CAPACITOR> or <CAPACITOR>C7031</CAPACITOR>.
The multimeter is not the problem, interpreting the reading is the problem.
